metadata.title: Nanomaterials based electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms for environmental applications

sections.text:
Nanomaterials based electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms for environmental applications
Govindhan Maduraiveerana,*, Wei Jinb,* aDepartment of Chemistry, Lakehead University, Thunder Bay, Ontario P7B 5E1, Canada bNational Engineering Laboratory for Hydrometallurgical Cleaner Production Technology, Key Laboratory of Green Process and Engineering, Institute of Process Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Article history: Received 15 February 2017 Received in revised form 16 February 2017 Accepted 17 February 2017
Keywords: Nanomaterial Modified electrode Electrochemical sensor Environmental monitoring Food safety
A B S T R A C T
A wide range of toxic chemicals is currently released into the environmental in terms of airborne, aquatic and solid wastes due to the rapid international globalization and industrialization. Thus, a sensitive, reliable and cost-effective sensor platform for emerging environmental pollutants is of great importance. The considerable advancements have been made on the successful electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms based on nanomaterials for environmental applications. In the present review, the recent trends in the development of the electrochemical sensor platforms based on state-of-the-art nanomaterials such as metal nanoparticles, metal oxide nanomaterials, carbon nanomaterials, polymer and biomaterials are assessed. The unique synthetic approaches, properties, integration strategies, selected sensing applications and future prospects of these nanostructured materials for the design of advanced sensor platforms are also highlighted. The significant development of the nanomaterials based electrochemical sensor platforms is giving rise to new impetus of generating novel technologies for securing the human and environmental safety.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, the development of analytical methods based on nanomaterials have made growing attention for numerous applications, including the fundamental biological research, monitoring of health, clinical diagnostics, pharmaceutical analysis, food safety and environmental monitoring. Owing to their exceptional physicochemical properties, high surface-to-volume ratio, high adsorption and reactive capacity and other beneficial properties not present in the bulk materials, nanomaterials have acted as potential analytical probe for not only offer enhanced sensitivity but also provide a stair change to analysis the single molecular realm [1]. Nanomaterials with unique functionalities and practises create promising development of the novel analytical systems that are easily triggered on exposure to emerging chemical pollutants as well as real time environmental monitoring in air, soil and water and food safety based on the essential to shield the environment and public health [2]. The major group of unregulated chemicals that can be classified majorly as heavy metals, inorganic anions, phenolic compounds, pesticides and chemical warfare reagents, which can cumulatively source severe damage to human health and environmental. Some of the pollutants are assumed of being cancer promoters and others have been associated with endocrine disrupting effects via food chain [3,4].
Over the recent decades, electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms with the integration of nanostructured materials have tremendously been employed as powerful analytical methods by captivating the benefit of easy-to-handle, cost-effective, high sensitive and selective, rapid response, facile-to-fabricate and portable. Fig. 1 shows the schematic illustration of the nanomaterial based electrochemical sensor and biosensor platform for environmental and food safety applications. As displayed in Fig.1, a number of electrochemical analytical techniques such as amperometric/potentiometric sensor, electrochemical impedance sensor, electrochemical luminescence sensor and photoelectrochemical sensor employ a wide range of chemical and biological analytes in terms of change in electrode interfaces via electrochemical route for numerous applications [5]. Diaz-Gonzalez et al. [6] recently reviewed the overview of the electroanalytical tools that
successfully applied for the detection of environmental pollutants recorded in the list of European Union (EU) set and other bodies. The advanced analytical methods using the combination of electrochemical devices in automatic fluidic structures that permitted the pre-conditioning sample and system standardisation is necessary for continuous environmental monitoring. These electroanalytical techniques have been employed with numerous sensor platforms wrapping a widespread range of nanomaterials and the fabrication convolution. Due to the significant realizations in nanoscience and nanotechnology, the amplification of electrochemical signal based on advanced nanomaterials have had a great prospective of enhancing both sensitivity and selectivity through novel functions such as effective catalytic activity, fast electrode kinetics, active large surface area, and control over the microenvironment of electrodes [7].
The structuring of the electrode surface at the nanoscale plays a crucial part in the development of high-performance electrochemical sensor platforms through numerous electrochemical fundamentals for the detection of target analytes [8]. The important motivation of the design of the nanoscale electrode materials is not only focus on the signal amplification via the catalytic activity and conductivity, but also likely to provide facile interactions with chemical and biological reagents and the immobilization of the functional moieties with precisely designed as signal tags, prominent to highly selective sensing [9]. Thus, the construction of the functional nanoscale electrode materials is recently advancing the wide environmental sensor applications. Besides the advantages of the fabrication of functional nanocomposite based sensor platforms, there are numerous characteristic drawbacks, including mass transport and electron transfer may be negatively impacted with functional and stabilization molecules and the recurrent occurrence of dissolution and aggregation of nanomaterials. The formation of nanocomposites or functional nanocomposites directly grown on the electrode surface, which is a promising resolution for the above discussed problems, as proposed by Govindhan et al. [10–12]. These necessary requirements should be instinctive while designing the electrode materials. The growing of advanced nanomaterials based electrochemical sensor platforms establishes a very effective and robust research field that may be anticipated to offer next generation electrochemical technologies for environmental analyses. A wideranging effort has been made on the expansion of electrochemical sensors and biosensors based on the functional nanostructured electrode materials, united with various electroanalytical methods, evolving the extensive environmental applications [13,14].
This review mainly concentrates on the recent advances in the development of nanostructured electrode materials based sensor and biosensor platforms for the detection of emerging environmental pollutants, which presents in the environment and food materials in order to protect human and environmental health. The present effort is to provide a perfect and brief vision of synthesis and properties of advanced nanomaterials, construction and the integration of the sensors based on nanomaterials. Furthermore, we highlight the latest development of the improved electrochemical sensors and the perspectives related to environmental applications rapidly emerging area may be taken in to consideration in future design, which may inspire broader interests in numerous area.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis and properties of nanomaterials
sections.text:
Owing to the numerous unique physical, chemical and biological properties of the nanomaterials and their nanocomposites, a significant effort has been invested on the development of the synthetic strategies with highly controllable size, shape, surface charge and physicochemical characteristics over the last
few decades [15]. Nanomaterials provide huge advantages on various applications, catalysis, imaging, biotechnological and sensor applications because of their improved properties. Three main paths have been employed for the production of the nanomaterials, including physical strategy (such as physical vapor deposition and laser ablation), chemical strategy (such as chemical vapor deposition, sol-gel processes, thermal decomposition and hydrothermal method), electrochemical (such as anodic oxidation and electrodeposition) and photochemical strategy (such as photodeposition) [16]. The integrations of the dimensional, compositional, geometric and structural properties of nanomaterials are vital to convey unique functionality and properties of the nanomaterials. The adsorption and interaction of the nanomaterials with chemical or biomolecules are key significant on the fabrication of nanomaterials for catalysis and sensor applications [17]. Several research groups have involved to address numerous concerns on the development of the nanomaterials for electrochemical sensor applications. The controlled size and composition, interfaces and distributions, nucleation and growth, stability, scale-up synthesis and assembly strategies for low-cost, large-scale production are main concerns of the synthesis of the nanomaterials [18]. There are numerous nanomaterials and their nanocomposites have employed for the environmental sensor applications because of the various attractive characteristics, including high chemical (bio) compatibility and inertness, easy to functionalize, huge surface energy and great electrode kinetics [19].
The high surface area to volume ratio of the nanomaterials allows enhanced catalytic and sensing response by the rapid movement of analytes through nanomaterials based electrodes or sensors. The excellent optical, magnetic, electrical and catalytic properties signify the profits over the macroscale materials, revealing the notable specific properties [20]. The physical and catalytic properties of the nanomaterials can be easily tuned or altered by the reduction of the spatial dimension or the confinement of the structures in a precise crystallographic direction. In particular, the properties of the nanomaterials are mainly associated to different origins via large fraction of surface atoms, large surface energy, spatial confinement, and the reduced imperfections. These can be tuned simply by adjusting the size, shape or extent of agglomeration [21]. Due to the enormous fraction of surface atoms in the total amount of atoms, nanomaterials possesses lower melting point and reduced lattice constants. The reduction of the materials dimension has obvious effects on the optical properties and the size and structure dependence can be categorized into surface plasmon resonance (SPR) and the quantum size effects [22]. The electrical conductivity decreases by increased surface scattering. The mechanism of electrical conductivity on the thin film can be extensively explained by a simple tunneling between localized insulating states, which imply a high resistivity at low temperatures[23]. For the catalytic property of the nanomaterials, geometry, composition, oxidation state, and chemical/physical environment can play a vital role in determining catalytic activity and reactivity of the nanomaterials, while particle size and shape is an important consideration. Thus, the relationship between these parameters and the catalytic performance of the nanomaterials may be system dependent. Moreover, a systematic understanding of the factor that control catalyst reactivity and selectivity is a vital [17,24].

sections.heading: 3. Noble metal nanomaterials
sections.text:
Owing to the unique size and shape dependent physical, chemical and electrochemical properties of the noble metallic nanomaterials such as gold (Au), silver (Ag), platinum (Pt), palladium (Pd) and their bimetallic alloys and core-shell
nanoparticles are predominantly fascinated for numerous environmental applications [25,26]. Metal nanoparticles play various key roles in the design of the electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms through a facile synthesis, ease of surface functionalization, stress-free sensor fabrication approach, catalysis of electrochemical reactions and the enhancement of an electron transfer process [27]. Recent years, metal nanoparticles based electrochemical sensor platforms provide a strong potential with enhancing both sensitivity and selectivity via tuned signal amplifications. With recent advances on the design of the metal nanoparticles, bio-functionalized nanoparticles and the effective nanocomposites with matrices have attracted for sensor and biosensor applications. The extensive research has led to the development of advanced numerous analytical methods for environmental monitoring and food safety applications.

sections.heading: 3.1. Gold nanoparticles
sections.text:
Significant efforts have been made on the development of the electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms based on Au nanoparticles for environmental applications due to the unique properties such as finely tunable optical properties, high surface area and capacity for the surface modification. The Au nanoparticles have successfully employed as an effective electrocatalyst in numerous electrochemical reactions because of their superior stability and complete recovery in chemical redox processes. The Au nanoparticles open the possibility for the miniaturization of sensing devices to the nanometer scale, which offer excellent chemical sensing prospects. Nanoscale electrochemical sensor based on Au via micro- and nanofabriation technologies offer a marvellous impending for the development of sensor array platforms for the electrochemical detection of environmental pollutants. In recent years, the integration capability of the sensor arrays with microfluidic devices provides possibilities for lab-on-achip technology for the sensing of multiple analytes in a highthroughput approach [28].
The use of Au nanoparticles based modified electrodes or nanosized electrodes offers numerous advantages such as improved diffusion of electroactive species, high selectivity, improved catalytic activity and higher signal-to-noise ratio (S/N). These properties are significant in the development of a nanostructured Au based electrode material for sensing analytes. A facile electrochemical sensor platform for the detection of arsenic ions (As3+) was developed based on Au nanoparticles by Huang co-workers [29], where an electrochemical approach for the characterization of the nanoscale effects of Au nanoparticles was established for electroanalytical applications. This sensor offered a simple and economical process for the fabrication of the electrode materials, which showed a high 16.15 mA mM 1 and a low detection limit of 32.5 pM. It is developed that the EDTA was effectively employed to eliminate interference from several metal ions. Mandler co-workers have reported that Au nanoparticles modified electrode surfaces exhibited a high sensitivity and sharper and more reproducible stripping peaks of mercury (Hg) [30]. A low detection limit was attained to be 1 mM L 1 for Hg, which was accomplished at the electrostatically adsorbed Au nanoparticles on ITO. They found that Hg preferentially strips from ITO rather than from Au and the presence of low amount of Au improves the detection limit by serving as nucleation sites for its deposition.
Nanoscale Au electrode material has been effectively employed as an amplified signal carrier for the design of several sensor platform. It is understood that the Au nanoparticles offer a convenient and stable connection between carrier and biomolecules, carrying high electrochemical response into the detection system. A sensor was established for the detection of mercuric ions
(Hg2+) with atto-molar detection limit (0.001 aM) [31]. Fig. 2 shows the schematic representation of the electrochemical sensor platform for the detection of Hg2+. Such a low detection limit was mainly attained by the graphene-Au and the signal amplification by nanoAu carrier strategy. For the selective and sensitive detection of the Hg2+, three single-stranded DNA probes were employed, which combined T-Hg2+-T coordination chemistry. A simple, disposable dual electrochemical sensor was developed for nitrate (NO3 ) and Hg2+ based on carbon print paper modified with the combination of selenium (Se) and Au nanoparticles [32]. The selection of Se nanoparticles act as an absorbing agent for Hg2+ and the Au nanoparticles catalyze the reduction of NO3 and Hg2+. The dual sensor exhibited an enhanced the sensitivity of NO3 and Hg2+ with detection limits of 8.6 mM and1.0 ppb, respectively.
In order to improve the stability and reproducibility of the sensor platform, much effort has been devoted to refresh the surface of the sensor for the detection of environmental pollutants. For instance, numerous methods such as vacuum annealing, laser ablation, flame etching, chemical oxidative etching, and electrochemical polarization have been employed to refresh the surface of the electrodes. However, these strategies easily lead to changes in surface chemistry and the structure of the electrode, and thus negatively affect the electron-transfer kinetics. Recently, Hu et al. established an approach to clean the electrodes via UV or visible light irradiation without affecting the activity of the electrodes. A refreshable photo-electrochemical sensor platform was developed for the detection of bisphenol A (BPA) based on Au nanoparticles modified with carbon doped TiO2 nanotube arrays (NTAs) [33]. The
developed sensor displayed an excellent electrochemical activity and high sensitivity (2.8 mA mM 1 cm 2) with the detection limit of 6.2 nM (S/N = 3) for BPA due to the combination of electrocatalytic properties and photocatalytic activities.

sections.heading: 3.2. Silver nanoparticles
sections.text:
Owing to the high conductivity, amplified electrochemical signal and excellent biocompatibility, the development of the Ag nanoparticles based sensor platform has made significant impact for environmental applications. Over last two decades, extensive effort has been made towards the design of novel analytical methods based on Ag nanoparticles and their nanocomposites for food safety and environmental monitoring. It has been succeeded that the Ag nanoparticles have recognised as one of the outstanding groups of the nanomaterials for electrochemical sensing and biosensing methods. Silver nanoparticles based electrode materials have unlocked up the opportunity of generating new analytical platforms for emerging environmental organic, inorganic and biological pollutants due to their high sensitive and specific nature [34,35].
The incorporation of the Ag nanoparticles into numerous matrixes such as metal oxides, silicate network, polymers, graphene, fibers, dendrimers, etc. provides enhanced sensing performance with high stability because of the extended utility of the materials. The sensitivity and stability of the sensor platform relate to the dispersion and the prevention of the aggregation process of the Ag nanoparticles in the network or matrices. Silver
ed. (Reprinted with permission from Ref. [31]). © 2015 American Chemical Society.
nanoparticles are stabilized via steric repulsion and electrostatic repulsion of the stabilizing agents with polymers or other matrices. For instance, Maduraiveeran et al. have developed an amperometric sensor platform based on Ag nanoparticle-silicate core-shell nanoparticles for the detection of nitroaromatic compounds [36]. The resulted sensor exhibited an excellent activity towards the sensing of nitroaromatics with a low detection limit of 5 nM. In addition, the sensor was stable for over five days with reproducible results due to the nanoparticles immobilization in the amine functionalized silicate network. Sadik co-workers have recently demonstrated an electrochemical sensor platform based on Ag nanoparticles embedded in the poly(amic) acid (PAA) polymer matrix (PAA-Ag NPs) for nitrobenzene [37]. The PAA–Ag nanoparticles based sensor exhibited a detection limit of 1.68 mM with a wide linear range of 10–600 mM and a high sensitivity of 7.88 mA mM 1 with minimal interference effects on structurallysimilar nitroaromatic compounds.
A label-free electrochemical biosensor platform was established with Ag nanoparticles on terminal deoxynucleotidyltransferase (TdT) extended ssDNA for the sensitive detection of Hg2+ [38]. The developed biosensor showed a high performance to Hg2+ sensing with a detection limit of 3 pM with good reproducibility and high selectivity towards other interfering metal ions. The developed simultaneous sensor for the detection of lead ions (Pb2 +), cadmium ions (Cd2+) and copper ions (Cu2+) was developed based on Ag nanoplates (Ag NPls) using a microfluidic paper-based analytical device (mPAD) coupled with dual electrochemical and colorimetric methods [39]. The low detection limit was found to be 0.1 ng mL 1 for all metals. This simultaneous sensor was successfully tested real samples and they were quantified with ICP-OES method, confirming the accuracy and reliability of the sensor. This could be useful for food and environmental analysis. Interestingly, Compton group recently developed a nano-electrochemical technique for the rapid detection of single influenza viruses tagged with the Ag nanoparticles [35]. In this analytical method, the Ag nanoparticles were adsorbed onto the surface of virus. The current spikes were recorded with sufficient applied potential to a carbon electrode, which related to the oxidation of the nanoparticles garnishing the virus. The current frequency and their magnitude were linear proportion to the concentration of virus and to the surface coverage of the nanoparticles, respectively.
Silver nanoparticles based electrochemical immunosensors combine the merits electrochemical technology and immunoassays in terms of a rapid response, high sensitivity and specificity and easy fabrication. They have attracted much attention for monitoring numerous analytes, including small organic and inorganic molecules, microorganisms, and virus. Zeng co-workers recently have developed a sensitive electrochemical immunosensor for the detection and determination of avian influenza virus H7 (AIV H7) using Ag nanoparticle-graphene (Ag NPs-GR) as labels in clinical immunoassays [40]. This sensor showed a low detection limit of 1.6 pg mL 1 with a wide working range of 1.6 mg to 16 ng mL 1. The developed electrochemical assay may potentially be employed to detect other pathogenic microorganisms.

sections.heading: 3.3. Platinum nanoparticles
sections.text:
Over the last decade, Pt nanoparticles have attracted much attention in the field of electrochemical sensors for various environmental applications because of their distinctive electronic and electrocatalytic properties. The properties of the Pt nanoparticles can be easily influenced through structure dependent interatomic bond distances, chemical reactivity and electronic properties. The electron-transfer process of the Pt nanoparticles can be significantly influenced by chemical composition, surface condition, crystal structure, crystallographic axis orientation and
other parameters. Platinum derived nanocomposites based electrode materials in sensors is an effective method towards the extension of their electronic and electrochemical properties [41].
Platinum nanoparticles based electrode materials can be prepared via chemical reduction, metal–vapor synthesis, electrochemical and photochemical deposition etc. The choice of the strategy is also play a key role to develop the Pt nanoparticles on the numerous electrode surface, which exhibits their superior chemical inertness, good stability, low background current, high catalytic and sensing performance [41–45]. Einaga co-workers have recently developed a sensor platform based on electrochemically deposited Pt nanoparticles on a boron-doped diamond surface (BDD) for the detection of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) [43]. The electrochemical deposition approach is suitable to construct the Pt nanoparticles on BDD electrode due to its simplicity and ease of fabrication. The detection limit was found to be 100 nM with a wide linear range of 0.05–20 mM. Further this sensor was then employed in immune-chromatographic strip test for melamine detection.
Research effort has been already established based on the application of microfluidics, which has encouraged the development of new analytical techniques for acting rapid analysis, high resolution and sensitivity. Amatore group has developed the analytical methods based on microchannel electrodes, which can be used to understand the mass transport regimes and increase the performance of the sensors [42]. The Pt-black coated Pt (Pt/Ptblack) based electrodes were microfabricated for the sensitive detection of H2O2 and nitrite (NO2 ) in PBS. The active surface area of the Pt/Pt-black electrodes permitted to escape inhibition effect, which led to perform the long term stability in contrast to the bare Pt electrodes. The Pt/Pt-black electrodes based sensor showed the detection limits of 10 and 12 nM for H2O2and NO2 respectively.
Platinum nanoparticles dispersed on graphene, mesoporous silica microspheres, metal oxide nanomaterials, etc. have successfully developed for the enhanced sensing of emerging pollutants. Hence, a design of novel composite nanomaterials is highly desirable for the construction of the advanced electrochemical sensors, in particular for nitroaromatic compounds. The PtPd concave nanocubes dispersed on graphene nanoribbons (PtPd-rGO NRs) were prepared via a hydrothermal process for the detection of trinitrotoluene (TNT) by Zhang et al. [44]. The PtPd-rGO NRs based sensor platform demonstrated a wide linear range from 0.01 to 3 ppm with a detection limit of 0.8 ppb for TNT. The electrochemical sensor for naphthol (NAP) isomers based on b-cyclodextrin (b-CD)-Pt nanoparticles (Pt NPs)/graphene nanosheets (GNs) nanohybrids (b-CD-PtNPs/GNs)[46]. This sensor showed a linear response range of 0.8–220 nM for a-NAP and 3–300 nM for b-NAP, with improved detection limits. Recently, Mahmoudian et al. have developed a sensitive electrochemical sensor for Hg2+ using a polypyrrole coated on nanospherical platinum (Pt/PPy NSs) [45]. The electrochemical sensor showed a linear range between 5– 500 nM with a detection limit of 0.27 nM for Hg2+. It exhibited a sensitivity of 1.239 mA nM 1 cm 2 with high selectivity from other interferences from Ag+, Fe2+, Mn2+, K+, Pd2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Pb2+, Sn2+ and Zn2+, presented a strong prospect for the detection of Hg2+.

sections.heading: 3.4. Palladium nanoparticles
sections.text:
Palladium nanoparticles have attracted much more interest due to their extensive catalytic and sensor applications towards gases, biomolecules and hazardous toxic molecules. The Pd nanoparticle based electrode materials exhibit high electrocatalytic activities towards various analytes. The abundance of Pd over other noble metals such as Au and Pd, which marks a cheaper substitute for utilization in the designing of various electrochemical sensing platforms. A diversity of Pd based nanomaterials, including of
metals, metal oxides and carbon nanomaterials with tailorable structures and variable composition have been effectively applied towards the detection of numerous pollutants due to their attractive electronic properties and high catalytic activities. The Pd based nanocomposites can improve the mass diffusion of the analytes, which offered electron tunneling to enable the electron transfer between the active site and the electrode, leading high electrochemical sensing performance.
A facile sensitive and simultaneous electrochemical sensor platform was developed for the detection of toxic metal ions using of the Pd nanoparticles (Pd NPs) dispersed on porous activated carbons (PACs) [47]. Due to the high porosities, high surface area and large pore volumes, the PACs are effectively employed as solid support for the dispersion of Pd nanoparticles, revealing the advantageous for the applications as a sensor platform for the detection of multiple Cd2+, Pb2+, Cu2+, and Hg2+ analytes with nanomolar detection limits. As shown in Fig. 3, the developed electrochemical sensor had demonstrated an excellent electrocatalytic activity, selectivity, sensitivity and low detection limit for detections of heavy metal ions even in a real milk sample. Owing to a synergistic effect between the Pd nanoparticles and the PACs, the sensor attained the improved electrochemical sensing performance. Wei co-workers developed a simultaneous sensor for ractopamine (RAC), salbutamol (SAL) and clenbuterol (CLB) based on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and Ag-Pd nanoparticles (AgPd NPs) [48]. Some Europe countries set a strict regulation for these molecules in animal foods as zero-tolerances. This multiplexed sensor showed a linear range from 0.01 to 100 ng mL 1 with detection limits of 1.52 pg mL 1, 1.44 mL 1 and 1.38 mL 1, respectively. In this sensor platform, the AgPd nanoparticles offered a

(d) Similar to (b) but in the presence of a mixture of a real milksample with m (10–20 mM). Electrolyte: 5 mL of milk extract with 5 mL of ABS (pH = 5). (Reprinted wit
strong electrochemical signal that can be employed to detect these molecules with high sensitivities.
Palladium nanoparticles embedded with polypyrrole (PPy) is an effective sensing electrode materials for a wide range of applications in various fields of research because of their outstanding properties. An electrochemical nitrate sensor was developed based on Pd nanoclusters with PPy (Pd NCs-PPy) by Silakhori et al. [49]. Differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) was employed for the detection of NO3 in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (PB) at pH 7. The Pd NCs-PPy based electrochemical sensor exhibited two linear plots. The first linear range increases from 100 to 800 mM, and the second linear range increases from 800 to 1400 mM. The low detection limit was found to be 0.45 mM. Sophia et al. have developed an electrochemical H2O2 sensor based on the Pd nanoparticles stabilized with polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) [50]. The vinyl polymers offer the capability to preserve the inherent catalytic activity of the metal nanoparticles intact with the chemical stability and the affinity of PVP vinyl polymer towards the Pd metal. The resulted sensor platform showed a detection limit of 8 nM with a wide range between 0.01 mM to 1 mM based on the amperometric results.

sections.heading: 4. Metal oxide nanomaterials
sections.text:
Metal oxides nanomaterials with large surface area, high adsorptive capacity, unique electrochemical activity and stability are of great importance for the design of electrochemical sensor platforms [51]. The analytical performance of the metal oxide nanomaterial based sensor can be well tuned by tailoring the properties of the morphology, particle size, surface area and surface functionality.
mM Cd2+, 3.2 mM Pb2+,6.0 mM Cu2+and 3.2 mM Hg2+. (b) DPV curves of the Pd1.5/PAC-

sections.heading: 4.1. Metal oxides nanoparticles
sections.text:
For the synthesis of nanostructured metal oxides, chemical methods comprise reduction of metal ions and controlled separation of the formed metal atoms from the bulk solution. They are quite favourable to obtain uniform nanoparticles such as nanorods, nanofibers, nanobelt, nanocomb and nanotubes. This family of one dimensional (1D) nanostructures provide a great model system for electrochemical sensing of environmental pollutants. Resistive (conductometric) gas sensors based on nanoscale metal oxide semiconductors such as SnO2, In2O3, ZnO, TiO2, WO3 and NiO play an important role in the environmental monitoring of explosive/toxic gases and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). The operating principle of resistive gas sensor is based on the variation of resistance (electrical conductivity) caused by the change of test gas molecules on the electrodes surface. In order to improve the sensitivity and detection limit, considerable efforts have been conducted on the design and controllable synthesis of the hierarchical metal oxides nanostructures due to their smaller size and characteristic charge carriers [52,53]. SnO2 nanoparticle is one of the most applied sensing materials for gas sensors.
Recently, Tyagi [54] has reported a hazardous sulfur dioxide (SO2) gas sensor using SnO2 thin film integrated with various nanosctuctured metal oxides (PdO, CuO, NiO, MgO, V2O5). It has been demonstrated the bare SnO2 thin film sensor exhibited the sensing response of about 1.3 at 220 C whereas, while NiO/SnO2 sensor presented an enhanced sensing response ( 56) towards 500 ppm SO2 gas at a low temperature of 180 C, as shown in Fig. 4.
Khong et al. [55] have designed a hierarchical SnO2/ZnO nanostructure for scalable preparation of the high-performance volatile ethanol sensors. First, high-quality single crystalline SnO2 nanowire (NW) backbones were fabricated via the thermal evaporation approach, subsequently ZnO nanorod (NR) branches were vertically grown to the axis of SnO2 NWs via the hydrothermal method. As compared to the bare SnO2 NWs sensor, the hierarchical nanostructures exhibited improved ethanol gas response and better selectivity for interfering gases such as NH3, CO, H2, and CO2.

sections.heading: 4.2. Metal oxides nanocomposites
sections.text:
On the other hand, the metal oxide can also be incorporated to nanocomposite for environmental sensing from the view of electrocatalysis. Kumar et al. [56] have developed a direct robust As(III) sensor using zirconia nanocubes modified gold electrode. Based upon the electrochemical oxidation behaviour of As, the sensing was achieved by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and chronoamperometry (CA) with an ultra-sensitivity of 550 nA cm 2 ppb 1, a detection limit of 5 ppb, and a wide linear range of 5–60 ppb with a response time of <2 sand is presented in Fig. 5. Huang et al. [57] have reported the combination of SnO2 and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) for the simultaneous and selective electrochemical determination of ultra-trace heavy metal ions in drinking water. Square wave anodic stripping voltammetry (SWASV) has been employed. The detection limit of 0.15 nM, 0.18 nM, 0.23 nM, and 0.27 nM were obtained towards Cd2+, Pb2+, Cu2+ and Hg2+, respectively, well satisfying the guideline value of the World Health Organization (WHO). Similarly, Wang et al. [58] have demonstrated a three-dimensional nanocomposite of rGO and Cu/ Cu2O nanocrystal (3D Cu/Cu2O@rGO) for detecting poisonous ractopamine (RAC), which was used illegally as feed additive for growth promotion in farm animals. As compared to pristine Cu2O nanospheres and porous rGO, ractopamine antibody (RACanti) tends to anchor onto the surface of 3D multi-functionalized Cu/ Cu2O@rGO nanocomposite, leading to more sensitive RAC detection with a low detection limit of 7.5 pg mL 1 and linear range of 0.1 ng mL 1 to 10.0 ng mL 1. The interference from other coexisting lean meat powders, urine components, and metal ions can be effectively eliminated.
Ionic liquids (ILs) are novel molten salts with the melting point close to or below room temperature, which comprise two asymmetrical ions of opposite charges [59]. The high conductivity, non-volatility and large electrochemical window make ILs promising for many electrochemical sensors applications. Gao et al. [60] developed a disposable As3+ detection platform by
integrating the high adsorptivity of Fe3O4 microspheres and the advantages of room temperature ionic liquid (RTIL). The Fe3O4RTIL nanocomposite modified screen-printed carbon electrode (SPCE) offered even better performance than commonly used noble metals, particularly with a high sensitivity of 4.91 mA ppb 1. Nanoscale metal oxide-based electrochemical sensors present a new protocol for the environmental monitoring.

sections.heading: 5. Carbon nanomaterials
sections.text: Carbonaceous materials exhibit excellent properties such as good conductivity, high stability, low cost, wide potential windows and easy surface functionalization [61]. Therefore, they have been widely designed and employed for various electroanalytical applications, particularly the emerged nanoscale carbon materials families of carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene and nano/ mesoporous carbon. Their nanostructures enable favourable exposure of surface groups for the binding between analyte molecules and transduction material, leading to remarkable detection performance for environmental pollutants [62,63].

sections.heading: 5.1. Carbon nanotubes
sections.text:
As one of the most commonly used building blocks of nanomaterials, carbon nanotubes have gained considerable attention since its discovery in 1991. CNTs can be visualized as cylindrical tubes ‘rolled’ up from sp2 hybridized graphene sheets, exhibiting 100 times tensile strength of steel, similar electrical conductivity to copper, and excellent electrocatalytic ability. They are classified into two types of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs), depending on single and multilayer graphene existed in the rolling honeycomb structures. Several methods have been developed to prepare CNTs [64], including chemical vapor deposition (CVD), electrical arc discharge and laser vaporization. It should be noted that the CVD is the most widely used commercial preparation approach, resulting from the thermal decomposition of hydrocarbon vapor (e.g., methane) in the presence of a metal catalyst. CVD is a simple, versatile and economic technique for CNTs fabrication, while it needs careful product purification to remove residual metals.
Due to the unique properties of large surface area, fast charge transfers as well as the compatibility and synergistic effect with the other electrode materials, many CNTs based environmental sensors have been developed, including composite, pastes, film, and functionalised CNT electrodes. Maduraiveeran et al. [65] have reported a single-walled carbon nanotube modified electrode for the simultaneous selective detection and determination of the toxic phenolic compounds (catechol, p-cresol and p-nitrophenol), which are widely present in aqueous and biological systems. This mediator-freesensor exhibited high sensitivity, good reproducibility and stability. Interestingly, Gooding et al. [66] have demonstrated the electroanalytical performance of individual SWNTs is more efficient than the corresponding MWNTs. The electron transfer rate is largely determined by the amount of surface oxides on the nanotubes that are exposed to the reactant. For the SWNT based electrodes, the oxygen-functionalized carbon nanotube is in direct contact with the solution, resulting in a fast electron transfer and excellent electrochemical detection. However, the reactions with MWNTs have been performed predominantly with nanotubes in the non-oriented style and the sidewalls were mainly presented to the solution, frustrating the charge transport and detection.
In order to further improve the electrochemical performance, many efforts have been conducted on the modification and integration of the carbon nanotubes. Zhao et al. [67] developed a polyamidosulfonicacid (PASA) film modified MWNTs for the
determination of hydroquinone and catechol. Due to the electrorich N atoms and high SO3 electron density in the polymer film, the response current at PASA/MWNTs/GC electrode is nearly two times higher than the sum of peak currents at the PASA/GC and MWNTs/GC electrodes. It is indicated that PASA/MWNTs composite film can act as an efficient mediator to improve the kinetics of the electrochemical reactions, resulting from the synergistic effect between the PASA and MWNTs.

sections.heading: 5.2. Graphene
sections.text:
Graphene is an emerged two-dimensional (2-D) nanomaterial of sp2 hybridized carbon sheet assembled in a honeycomb lattice, resulting in an extremely high surface area (theoretically 2630 m2g 1, almost twice as that of SWCNTs). Besides, it is a semiconductor with a zero band-gap, exhibiting ambipolar electric field effect with high charge carrier mobility (15,000–20,000 cm2/ Vs). Furthermore, graphene also possesses superior mechanical and thermal characteristics. Obviously, these excellent physicochemical and electrical properties enable graphene an exciting attractive candidate for the fabrication of electrochemical sensor electrode.
Graphene was first isolated in 2004 via facile scotch-tape exfoliation of highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) [61]. Recently, many scalable, cost-effective and high-yield production processes have been developed, such as the rGO (Hummers method), electrochemical reduction, and chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [68,69]. It has been demonstrated that mechanical exfoliation can generate graphene with basal planes structures, high conductivities but decreased electrochemical activities, while the methods involving chemical oxidations and reduction can produce high electrochemical activity due to the increasing defects and functional groups. Besides, the inevitable metal contamination in the CVD method can contribute to the electrochemical behaviour of final product, addressing the necessity of accurate metal species control during the fabrication process [70].
As discussed earlier, the geometry and electrochemical properties of graphene makes it ideal transduction materials for environmental sensing. Goh et al. [71] have developed the graphene nanoribbons-based electrodes toward the sensitive electrochemical detection of explosive 2, 4, 6-trinitrotoluene (TNT), which is a common environmental “ticking bombs” in seawater. The limit of detection of TNT in untreated seawater was 1 mg mL 1. Luo et al. [72] have reported a convenient electroanalytical detection of carcinogenic hydrazine and nitrite by synergetic grapheme-cobalt hexacyanoferrate nanocomposite, resulting in the reduced oxidation overpotentials and increased current response of the target analytes. The analytical platform was also well demonstrated by the evaluation of water samples and pickled food, in which the average recovery was found to be >92.2%.
Furthermore, graphene-based nanomaterials have been also successfully employed in the monitoring of gaseous pollutants and heavy metal contaminants. Li et al. [73] have fabricated graphenebased devices via alternating current dielectrophoresis (ac-DEP) for nitric oxide (NO) gas determination. The as-prepared device is consisted of the sensitive channels of Pd-decorated rGO (Pd-RGO) and the chemical vapor deposition (CVD)-grown grapheme electrodes. As a result, highly sensitive, reusable and reliable NO detection ranging from 2 to 420 ppb with response time of 700 s has been obtained at room temperature. Dai et al. [74] have developed an electrochemical sensor based on functionalized polypyrrole (PPy)/GO for the detection of heavy metal ions. The PPy/GO nanocomposites were fabricated by in-situ chemical oxidation polymerization and electrostatic functionalization, exhibited high electrochemical conductivity and remarkable current increase as compared to PPy/GO and PA/GO modified
electrodes. This modified electrode employed to measure Cd2+ and Pb2+ with a wide linear working range of 5–150 mg L 1, as presented in Fig. 6.

sections.heading: 5.3. Porous carbon
sections.text:
Porous carbon with a high surface area, accessible surface chemistry, and short pathway for mass and electron transfer has attracted considerable attention due to the promising applications in electrochemical sensors. According to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) recommendation, porous carbon materials can be grouped into three classifications based upon their pore sizes: microporous <2 nm, 2 nm <mesoporous <50 nm, and macroporous >50 nm [75]. Ma et al. [76] have developed a sensitive electrochemical nitrobenzene (NB) sensor based on macro-/meso-porous carbon materials, which were fabricated by pyrolysis of the ionic liquid([AEIm]BF4) polymer (PIL) pre-wrapped onto SiO2 microspheres and then removal of the silica core. Owing to the large specific surface area and accumulation effect in this porous structure, the MMPCMs modified electrode presents stable, reproducible analytical performance for NB detection with a linear response range of 0.2–40 mM and the detection limit of 8 nM. Niu et al. [77] have reported a bismuth porous carbon nanocomposite based screen-printed electrodes (SPEs) for the heavy metal detection. The nanocomposite was synthesized by a combined one-step sol-gel and pyrolysis process, followed by the milling down to a specific particle size distribution for the screen printing ink. The resulting electrodes were successfully applied to the detection of Pb2+ and Cd2+ ions at concentration levels below 4 ppb in tap drinking water and wastewater systems.
Recently, biomass-derived porous carbon is of great interest because it can be readily prepared from the carbonization of low cost precursors. Wang et al. [78] have proposed a threedimensional (3D) macroporous carbon (3D-KSCs) derived from kenaf stem (KS) as a novel supporting material for electrochemical sensing platform. The integrated cobalt nanoparticles/3D-KSCs nanocomposite electrode shows a 3D honeycomb porous structure, exhibiting good electrocatalytic performances toward the oxidation and detection of amino acid. Therefore, a linear range from 0.10 to 18.60 mM with a sensitivity of 32.11 mA cm 2mM 1 and a low detection limit of 0.05 mM was obtained for the N-acetyl cysteine sensor. A linear range from 0.15 to 26.24 mM with a sensitivity of 42.24 mA cm 2mM 1 and a low detection limit of 0.02 mM were achieved for the detection of cysteine. Similarly, Veerakumar et al. [79] have reported the palladium nanoparticles (Pd NPs) on porous activated carbons (PACs) electrodes for the
Fig. 6. (a) Electrochemical behaviour and (b) corresponding calibration plots of PA/pp permission from Ref. [74]). © 2016 Elsevier.
detection of toxic metal ions. The PACs were derived from waste biomass feedstock (fruit peels), possessing desirable textural properties and favourable porosities for the uniform dispersion of Pd nanoparticles (ca. 3–4 nm). The Pd/PAC modified electrodes showed superior performances for the individual and simultaneous detection of toxic heavy metal ions of Cd2+, Pb2+, Cu2+, and Hg2+.

sections.heading: 6. Polymer and bio-nanomaterials
sections.text: Polymer and bio-nanomaterials based electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms offer improved sensitivity with rapid response and selectivity due their radiant, electrical, catalytic, mechanical, thermal and physical properties [80]. With increasing the structural and functional complexity of polymeric and biomaterials, it is very difficult to envisage the desired sensing properties. The design and the development of the electrochemical sensor platforms for detecting emerging environmental pollutants based on polymeric and bio-nanomaterials with unique functionalities and properties can be presently accomplished by combining the novel analytical and scientific methods, including of combinatorial and high-throughput materials screening with micro- and nanofabrication and microfluidics [81].

sections.heading: 6.1. Polymer nanomaterials
sections.text:
Effort on the development of polymeric nanomaterials, including homo- and copolymers, formulated materials, polymeric structures with engineered morphology, and molecular shaperecognition materials have been established for the sensitive sensing of food and environmental pollutants [82]. With unique properties, polymeric nanomaterials deliver a desirable variety in electrochemical analytical strategies for the detection and determination of the chemically and biological toxic analytes in gases and liquids for numerous health and environmental applications [83]. The polymeric nanomaterials based sensor platforms have exhibited several properties, including intrinsic properties of sensitivity, linearity, selectivity and the ease of manufacturability. The formation of self-assembled bio-membranes, electro-polymerized polymers (conducting polymers, CPs) and dendrimers based polymeric nanomaterials have motivated extensive devotion in the design of sensor platforms. Further improve their electrochemical sensing properties, the fabrication of the nanocomposites with metal nanoparticles, metal oxide nanoparticles, (carbon nanotube) CNT and graphene [84,85]. With highlighting the important achievements in design of sensor platforms, the combination of the matrix and nanofiller
y/GO electrodes for the simultaneous detection of Cd2+and Pb2+. (Reprinted with
contributions are pronounced to enhance the biocompatibility, excellent sensitivity and selectivity.
The polyaniline (PANI) nanofibers modified with bentonite nanohybrid was employed for gas sensor application towards toxic gases such as acetone, benzene, ethanol and toluene [86]. It was found the sensitivity of the developed sensor to the analyte gases followed the following order: acetone > benzene > toluene > ethanol. The selectivity of the developed sensor was ascribed to two factors including (i) the effect of vapor pressure of the gas analytes, and (ii) the formation of dipolar, and p-electron delocalization interactions between the nanohybrid and the gas analytes. Navale et al. have developed the gas sensing properties of polypyrrole (PPy)/a-Fe2O3 nanocomposites various oxidizing (NO2 and Cl2) and the reducing (CH3OH, C2H5OH, H2S and NH3) gases at room temperature [87]. The developed gas sensor showed a fast response, stability and shorter recovery times as compared to PPy, revealed the excellent gas sensing properties at room temperature, which can be used as high performance selective NO2 gas sensors. Recently, Lee et al. have developed an sensor platform for hydrazine (N2H4) using poly(dopamine) (pDA)modified indium tin oxide (ITO) electrode [88]. CV technique
was employed to study the electrocatalytic oxidation of N2H4. The pDA based sensing electrode acts as a mediator for the electrochemical reaction, which exhibited good performance towards the detection of N2H4. The prepared sensor displayed a linear range from 100 mM to 10 mM with a detection limit 1 mM.
The molecular imprinting ploymers (MIP) is a division of polymeric nanomaterials, which are effective approach for high selective detection of molecules through artificial recognition. This is a straight-forward strategy to enable analytical chemists to produce synthetic polymers, which are selective towards a specified template through complementary non-covalent binding sites. This is mainly based on ionic, hydrophobic or hydrogen bond interactions [89]. The MIPs based electrochemical sensors can be employed for the detection of a wide range of analytes, including drugs, pesticides, peptides, sugars, organic compounds, viruses, erythrocytes and immunoglobulin. Pingarron co-workers have established a biosensor based on the nanocomposites of electropolymerized network of polyamidoamine dendrimer-coated Au nanoparticles for the amperometric sensing of catechol in 0.1 M PB (pH 7.0) [84]. The prepared biosensor showed a detection of 20 nM with a wide linear range of 50 nM–10 mM. In addition, the biosensor was stable over 30 days when the sensor was kept at 4 C. This can be ascribed to the glutaraldehyde-mediated multipoint attachment of the enzyme to the primary amino groups at the surface of the poly(amidoamine) (PAMAM) hyper-branched structures capping the Au nanoparticles-polymers network.
Another electrochemical immunosensor was developed based on the antigen–antibody immune reaction using single-walled carbon nanohorns (SWCNHs)–hollow Pt nanospheres/dendrimer for procalcitonin (PCT) [90]. The combination of high specific surface area of SWCNHs and the catalytically active Pt nanoparticles were comprised in the biosensor. The PAMAM dendrimer was used to increase the quantity of the electrochemically active compound thionine immobilized on the surface, which offered a diamine core and an amidoamine branching structure. This biosensor exhibited the high sensitivity, improved stability and ideal selectivity with a wide linear response from 10 pg mL 1 to 20 ng mL 1. The limit of detection was found to be 1.74 pg mL 1, revealed that this immunosensor might offered a new option for clinical septicemia diagnosis through PCT detection.

sections.heading: 6.2. Bio-nanomaterials
sections.text:
The integration of the biomolecules with nanoscale objects provide numerous platforms which combine the characteristics of the nanomaterials and catalytic function of biomolecules. A welldefined nanostructure with biomaterials can be obtained by the self-organization of biological molecules. These bio-nanomaterials inspire the analytical researchers for biomedical and environmental applications [91]. On the development of advanced electrochemical sensor platforms, great efforts have been made with a new generation of composite of nanostructured materials, which emerge the sensor field in the frontier between materials science, life science, and nanotechnology. The bio-nanomaterials become to elect nanocomposites, which involve enzymes, antibodies (antigens), or DNA and a naturally occurring polymer (biopolymer) in the arrangement with an inorganic moiety at least one dimension on the nanometer scale. Due to the unique recognition, transport, electronic and catalytic properties, the bio-nanomaterials offer highly selective catalytic and recognition properties of biomaterials, such as proteins/enzymes, nucleic acids, biopolymers, etc. Biomaterials consist of biomolecules, which are attractive macromolecular structures in terms of their unique recognition, transport, electronic and catalytic properties. A numerous electrochemical sensor platforms have developed based
on bio-nanomaterials for the detection of emerging environmental pollutants and food safety applications [80,92,93].
Bisetty co-workers have developed an electrochemical biosensor for capsaicin, which extracted from chillifruits, using with a nanobiocomposite of L-phenylalanine ammonia-lyase enzyme [92]. In this biosensor platform, the nanocomposite of MWNTs and phenylalanine ammonia-lyase enzyme immobilized on the Pt electrode surface was designed. The established biosensor exhibited a low detection limit of 0.18 mg mL 1. The interaction of the PAL enzyme with the phenolic component of the capsaicin is a vital role to enhance the sensitivity of the developed biosensor platform. Due to the high specificity, controllability, robustness and ability to function under a wide range of temperatures and
condition, DNA-based biosensor platforms have attained much interest in the fields of environmental and health care. The employment of DNA-DNAhybridization, protein-DNA recognition, etc. based biosensors have been developed for the analysis of numerous target analytes. For example, recently, Wang et al. have demonstrated sensitive electrochemical biosensor platform based on the Au nanoparticles decorated bovine serum albumin and rGO (Au NPs-BSA-rGO) for the detection of Hg2+ [94]. This resulted sensor platform exhibited a detection limit of 0.03 nM with a wide range between 0.1 and 130 nM.
The real-time measurement of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) was employed by Du co-workers through reactivation from a postexposure by considering inter- or intra-individual variation in the
normal levels of AChE for the detection of organophosphorus pesticides (OPs) poisons [95]. As shown in Fig. 7, the fabrication of sensor platform based on core–shell Fe3O4/Au NPs nanocomposites and the process of the electrochemical oxidative desorption for thiocholine. The measurement of AChE activity from OPexposed sample and the parallel measurement of AChE activity are schematically illustrated in Fig. 7. This OP sensor showed a linear concentration range of 0.05–5 nM. To enhance the adsorption capacity, stability, and retain activity of the bio-nanomaterials, self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) approach is widely employed to functionalize the surface of the electrode. For instance, with the amide bond formation, the reaction can be held between amino group of protein and reactive succinimidyl group of the 3- dithiobis-(sulfosuccinimidylpropionate) using the covalent binding formation on the SAM electrode surface.
On the electrode modification with biomaterials, the short selfassembling time with mild reaction condition enhances the performance of the biosensors. Li et al. have developed an electrochemical impedance immunosensor for the detection of Escherichia coli O157:H7 based on SAM approach [93]. The signal of the impedance can be altered by the immobilization of the biomaterials onto the surface of the printed interdigitated microelectrodes (SPIMs). This developed immunosensor showed a low detection limit of 101 cfu mL 1 and a linear range from 102 to 107 cfu mL 1. This biosensor may use in food safety analysis, which may lead to a portable biosensor method for routine monitoring of foodborne pathogens.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions and future outlooks
sections.text:
Development of nanoscale electrode materials for the environmental monitoring and food safety applications has gained significant importance, in terms of new functionality, high sensitivity and specificity as a robust sensor platform. This review has provided a brief summary of the recent advances in the design of electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms, which are empowered by the unique physicochemical and electrochemical properties of the nanomaterials, lead to enhance the development of advanced applications. A list of numerous nanomaterial based electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms for environmental applications discussed in the present review is summarized in Table 1. The fabrication of the nanomaterial based electrochemical sensors have been illustrated over the past two decades due to the ascription of the exceptional intriguing properties, easy surface functionalization, favourable compatibility, high electrochemical activity, the great mass and electron transfer property of the nanomaterials. There is a necessary for the design of advanced nanomaterials to require to achieve high sensitivity, selectivity and stability of the sensor and biosensor platforms. The following related problems to reflect in the construction of novel nanomaterials include: (i) size and shape controlled synthesis – to attain the optimal electrochemical active sites, (ii) bi- or trimetallic nanomaterials optimization and architectures – to improve the specificity and stability, (iii) discovery of functional molecule – to provide high specificity with analytes, (iv) correlation between composition, structure, and reactivity of nanomaterials – to design novel nanomaterials with exceptional selectivity, (vi) discovery of high conductive, chemical and mechanical stable and great surface area of substrate materials– to improve the electrochemical properties, and (vii) design of the nanometric interfaces – to offer a great platform for the exceptional electrocatalytic properties, improve the sensitivity and stability of the sensor platform.
The key factors such as shape, size, architecture, composition, and functionalization are mainly involved in the enhanced performance of the electrochemical sensor and biosensor
platforms. Owing to the advances in the nanomaterials synthesis, sensor fabrication, integration and testing analytical measurements, the fast and online-monitoring of emerging environmental pollutants may offer a possible elucidation towards the recognition of the highly sensitive sensors. Besides the development of the sensors with high sensitivity, rapid response and low-cost, the direct analytical measurements of the developed sensors in the commercial environmental and food monitoring industries is an another milestone because of the lack of extensive combined efforts between multidisciplinary science and engineering disciplines. This review has delivered a model framework to expedite the emergence of advances to address the tasks that presently obstruct the usage of nanomaterials various electrochemical sensor/biosensor applications, and drawn the requests for future development. It is expected that the advances of electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms based on nanomaterials will be comprehended to implement of the corresponding directives to provide a better life for society in the near future with continuous effort on the advancement.

metadata.abstractText: A wide range of toxic chemicals is currently released into the environmental in terms of airborne, aquatic and solid wastes due to the rapid international globalization and industrialization. Thus, a sensitive, reliable and cost-effective sensor platform for emerging environmental pollutants is of great importance. The considerable advancements have been made on the successful electrochemical sensor and biosensor platforms based on nanomaterials for environmental applications. In the present review, the recent trends in the development of the electrochemical sensor platforms based on state-of-the-art nanomaterials such as metal nanoparticles, metal oxide nanomaterials, carbon nanomaterials, polymer and biomaterials are assessed. The unique synthetic approaches, properties, integration strategies, selected sensing applications and future prospects of these nanostructured materials for the design of advanced sensor platforms are also highlighted. The significant development of the nanomaterials based electrochemical sensor platforms is giving rise to new impetus of generating novel technologies for securing the human and environmental safety. © 2017 Elsevier B.V.
